title: 1185-F
statement: F. Two Pizzastime limit per test4 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA company of $$$n$$$ friends wants to order exactly two pizzas. It is known that in total there are $$$9$$$ pizza ingredients in nature, which are denoted by integers from $$$1$$$ to $$$9$$$.Each of the $$$n$$$ friends has one or more favorite ingredients: the $$$i$$$-th of friends has the number of favorite ingredients equal to $$$f_i$$$ ($$$1 \\le f_i \\le 9$$$) and your favorite ingredients form the sequence $$$b_{i1}, b_{i2}, \\dots, b_{if_i}$$$ ($$$1 \\le b_{it} \\le 9$$$).The website of CodePizza restaurant has exactly $$$m$$$ ($$$m \\ge 2$$$) pizzas. Each pizza is characterized by a set of $$$r_j$$$ ingredients $$$a_{j1}, a_{j2}, \\dots, a_{jr_j}$$$ ($$$1 \\le r_j \\le 9$$$, $$$1 \\le a_{jt} \\le 9$$$) , which are included in it, and its price is $$$c_j$$$.Help your friends choose exactly two pizzas in such a way as to please the maximum number of people in the company. It is known that a person is pleased with the choice ifeachof his/her favorite ingredients is in at least one ordered pizza. If there are several ways to choose two pizzas so as to please the maximum number of friends, then choose the one that minimizes the total price of two pizzas.InputThe first line of the input contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 10^5, 2 \\le m \\le 10^5$$$) â€” the number of friends in the company and the number of pizzas, respectively.Next, the $$$n$$$ lines contain descriptions of favorite ingredients of the friends: the $$$i$$$-th of them contains the number of favorite ingredients $$$f_i$$$ ($$$1 \\le f_i \\le 9$$$) and a sequence of distinct integers $$$b_{i1}, b_{i2}, \\dots, b_{if_i}$$$ ($$$1 \\le b_{it} \\le 9$$$).Next, the $$$m$$$ lines contain pizza descriptions: the $$$j$$$-th of them contains the integer price of the pizza $$$c_j$$$ ($$$1 \\le c_j \\le 10^9$$$), the number of ingredients $$$r_j$$$ ($$$1 \\le r_j \\le 9$$$) and the ingredients themselves as a sequence of distinct integers $$$a_{j1}, a_{j2}, \\dots, a_{jr_j}$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_{jt} \\le 9$$$).OutputOutput two integers $$$j_1$$$ and $$$j_2$$$ ($$$1 \\le j_1,j_2 \\le m$$$, $$$j_1 \\ne j_2$$$) denoting the indices of two pizzas in the required set. If there are several solutions, output any of them. Pizza indices can be printed in any order.ExamplesInput3 4 2 6 7 4 2 3 9 5 3 2 3 9 100 1 7 400 3 3 2 5 100 2 9 2 500 3 2 9 5Output2 3Input4 3 1 1 1 2 1 3 1 4 10 4 1 2 3 4 20 4 1 2 3 4 30 4 1 2 3 4Output1 2Input1 5 9 9 8 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 3 4 1 2 3 4 1 4 5 6 7 8 4 4 1 3 5 7 1 4 2 4 6 8 5 4 1 9 2 8Output2 4

processed.result:
There are $n$ friends who each have a list of favorite pizza toppings.  There are $m$ pizzas available, each with a price and a list of toppings.  

You need to choose two pizzas to order that will please as many friends as possible. A friend is pleased if at least one of their favorite toppings is on one of the chosen pizzas. If there are multiple ways to choose two pizzas that please the same number of friends, choose the two pizzas with the lowest total price.

**Input:**

* The first line contains two integers, $n$ and $m$, representing the number of friends and the number of pizzas, respectively.
* The next $n$ lines each describe a friend's favorite toppings. Each line starts with an integer $f_i$ (the number of favorite toppings) followed by $f_i$ integers representing the friend's favorite toppings.
* The next $m$ lines each describe a pizza. Each line starts with the pizza's price $c_j$, followed by an integer $r_j$ (the number of toppings) and then $r_j$ integers representing the pizza's toppings.

**Output:**

* Output two integers, $j_1$ and $j_2$, representing the indices of the two pizzas to order.

You have a group of people, each with a list of favorite items. There are several options to choose from, each with a price and a set of items.  You need to pick two options to maximize the number of people who have at least one of their favorite items covered. If there are multiple solutions, choose the cheapest one.
